title: Synthetic Recap
body:
HOUSTON (AP) — The box score from Sunday night reads like a misprint, a statistical anomaly from a bygone era. But for the Houston Rockets, the 104-95 victory over the Golden State Warriors was not about the final score. It was about bearing witness to one man’s singular, Herculean will.

In a performance for the ages, Hakeem Olajuwon authored a masterpiece, pouring in a staggering 49 points to carry the Rockets on his back. From the opening tip, it was clear the Warriors had no answer for "The Dream." He was an unstoppable force in the paint, a whirlwind of spin moves, drop-steps, and feathery-soft jump hooks that defied logic and defense.

Golden State, led by Joe Smith’s 22 points, fought valiantly, but they were merely spectators to a historic event. Every time they threatened to close the gap, Olajuwon would demand the ball on the block and deliver another crushing blow. His 49 points weren't just a high total; they were a declaration, accounting for over half of his team's offensive output and leaving the Summit crowd in a state of rapturous disbelief.

While Clyde Drexler chipped in a quiet 15 points, this night belonged solely to the legendary center. Olajuwon’s monumental effort was more than enough to overcome the Warriors’ balanced attack, rendering the rest of the game’s details a mere footnote.

In the record books, it will be a simple win for the Rockets. But for those who saw it, it was a night Hakeem Olajuwon transcended the sport, delivering one of the most dominant individual performances the game has ever seen.
